metadata.background_text:
Reading the Inaugurals 

         President Clinton's Inaugural Address this month is the 53 rd in the series that began in 1789. All are worth a read--not just the highlights, such as George Washington, Abraham Lincoln, and FDR. They will give you a feeling of being there, not as an omniscient historian of 1997 looking back at 1837 or 1897 but as an ordinary citizen who shares--and is limited by--the information, the concerns, and the values of those times. (Thanks to Columbia University, all the addresses can be found on the Web.) 

         Among all the past presidents and their speech writers there was only one literary genius: Lincoln. After 132 years, his second inaugural still brings tears to your eyes and chills your blood. None of the other inaugural addresses are in that league. But by and large they are dignified and intelligent speeches given by articulate men, each in touch with his times and aware that his inauguration was the most solemn occasion of his life. 

         The stance and style of the inaugurals seem to have gone through three phases. The first, lasting until Lincoln, was that of the modest, classic public servant. The second, lasting through William Howard Taft, was of the prosaic government executive. The third, in which we are still, is the phase of the assertive, theatrical leader-preacher. This classification is not waterproof. Theodore Roosevelt may belong in the third phase and Warren G. Harding-Calvin Coolidge-Herbert Hoover in the second. But the trend is clear. 

         On picking up Washington's first inaugural, one is immediately struck by the modesty. He had just been elected unanimously by the Electoral College. He was more respected than any subsequent president has been at the time of his inauguration. And what does he say? 

                         [T]he magnitude and difficulty of the trust to which the voice of my country called me, being sufficient to awaken in the wisest and most experienced of her citizens a distrustful scrutiny into his qualifications, could not but overwhelm with despondence one who (inheriting inferior endowments from nature and unpracticed in the duties of civil administration) ought to be peculiarly conscious of his own deficiencies.              

          None of his successors has made the point as forcefully as that. But echoes are to be found in almost every president for the next 68 years. (John Adams was an exception. He was apparently so envious of Washington that he spent a large part of his address spelling out his own excellent qualifications for the job.) That era ended with Lincoln. Subsequent inaugurals routinely contain protestations of humility, but they are perfunctory and do not sound sincere. 

         The antebellum modesty, while in part a reflection of the conventional etiquette of the time, may also have served a political objective: to alleviate the concerns of those who--in the early days of the republic--feared it might be transformed into a monarchy, and the president into a king. A little later, perhaps after 1820, a new worry arose. Would the power of the federal government be used to interfere with the "peculiar domestic institution" of the Southern states? The presidents' assurance of the limitation of their powers may have been intended to give comfort to those states. 

         Lincoln faced a different situation. With the South already seceding, he could only "preserve, protect and defend the Constitution" by asserting the power of the federal government and his own power as chief executive. It was no time for modesty. Lincoln's successors inherited a federal government with much more authority--and more need to use it--than before the war, and they had less motivation to belittle themselves and their powers. 

         In the third phase, the Inaugural Address metamorphosed from describing the government's policy to inspiring the public's behavior. Presidents recognized--or, at least, believed--that the country had problems they ought to deal with but could not manage by using the instruments of government alone. Thus, in his first inaugural, Woodrow Wilson said: "At last a vision has been vouchsafed us of our life as a whole. We see the bad with the good, the debased and decadent with the sound and the vital. With this vision we approach new affairs." 

         If the country is debased and decadent, the cure has to come from uplifting the people, not from acts of government. Similar diagnoses and prescriptions appear in later inaugurals. 

          Presidents derived their license to serve as leader-preacher from Theodore Roosevelt's remark that the presidency was "a bully pulpit," a remark that did not appear in his Inaugural Address. The metaphor of the pulpit suggests not reading but oral and visual contact between the preacher and his flock. Radio and--even more--television made this possible on a national scale. A telltale sign of the leader-preacher inaugural is the use of the phrase, "Let us ... "--meaning, "You do as I say." This expression appears occasionally throughout the history of inaugurals, but it has hit its stride in recent years. John F. Kennedy repeated it 16 times in his Inaugural Address, and Richard Nixon has it 22 times in his second one. 

         The change in literary style from classical to colloquial can be demonstrated by one statistic. In all the inaugurals from Washington through James Buchanan, the average number of words per sentence was 44. From Lincoln to Wilson it was 34, and since Wilson it has been 25. I do not consider this a deterioration (this article has an average of 17 words per sentence), but it does reflect the change in the size and character of the audience and in the means of communication. William Henry Harrison could talk about the governments of Athens, Rome, and the Helvetic Confederacy and expect his audience to know what he was talking about. That wouldn't be true today. But Harrison's audience would not have known what the Internet was. 

         Presidents and their speech writers have mined their predecessors for memorable words and repeated them without attribution. Kennedy's trumpet call, "Ask not what your country can do for you: Ask what you can do for your country," has an ironic history. In his inaugural, Harding, surely no model for Kennedy, had said, "Our most dangerous tendency is to expect too little of government, and at the same time do for it too little." And even before he became president, in a speech in 1916, Harding had said, "In the great fulfillment we must have a citizenship less concerned about what the government can do for it and more anxious about what it can do for the nation." 

         Many an issue frets its hour on the inaugural stage and then is heard no more. That includes the Indians, the coastal fortifications, territorial expansion, the Isthmus Canal, civil-service reform, polygamy, and Prohibition. Some subjects that you expect to appear, don't. Hoover's inaugural, March 4, 1929, gives no hint of economic vulnerability. Roosevelt's second inaugural, Jan. 20, 1937, contains no reference to Hitler or to Germany. But what is most amazing, at least to a reader in 1997, is the silence of the inaugurals on the subject of women. The word "women" does not appear at all until Wilson's first inaugural, and it always appears as part of the phrase "men and women," never as referring to any special concerns of women. Even Harding, the first president to be chosen in an election in which women voted nationally, does not remark on the uniqueness of the fact in his inaugural. 

          One subject that does get ample treatment is taxes. "Taxes," or some equivalent word, appears in 43 of the 52 inaugural addresses to date. Coolidge said in 1925: "The time is arriving when we can have further tax reduction. ... I am opposed to extremely high rates, because they produce little or no revenue, because they are bad for the country, and, finally, because they are wrong." Federal taxes were then about 3 percent of the gross domestic product. Ronald Reagan said essentially the same thing in 1981, when they were 20 percent. 

         The most disturbing aspect of the whole series of inaugurals is what is said and unsaid on the subject of race relations, which Arthur Schlesinger Jr. calls "the supreme American problem." The words "black," "blacks," "Negro," or "race" (as applied to blacks) do not appear at all until Rutherford Hayes, 1877. James Monroe asked in 1817, "On whom has oppression fallen in any quarter of our Union? Who has been deprived of any right of person or property?" These were rhetorical questions, intended to get the answer "No one!"--as if there were not millions of slaves in America. 

         Before the Civil War the word "slavery" appears only in the Inaugural Address of Martin Van Buren, 1837, and Buchanan, 1857, and then only as something that, pursuant to the Constitution and in order to preserve the Union, should not be interfered with. But although generally unmentionable, the subject was boiling, and would boil over in 1861. After the Civil War, it is in the inaugurals of Hayes, James Garfield (1881), and Benjamin Harrison (1889) that we find the most explicit and positive discussion of the need to convert into reality the rights and freedom granted to the "freedmen" on paper by the 13 th , 14 th , and 15 th amendments. Garfield's was the strongest among these. (He had been a student at Williams College in the 1850s, 80 years before me, when the college had been a station on the underground railway.) But the subject then began to fade. William McKinley said in his first Inaugural Address, March 4, 1897, "Lynchings must not be tolerated in a great and civilized country like the United States," but he said it without horror. Taft raised the subject of race relations in 1909 only to express satisfaction at the progress that had been made. And then the subject disappeared. FDR never mentioned it in any of his four inaugurals. 

         After World War II the subject came back to inaugural addresses, but in a weak and abstract form. That is true even of the presidents we think of as being most concerned with race relations in America--like Harry Truman, Lyndon Johnson, and Bill Clinton. Perhaps each thought he had made a sufficient statement by having a black woman--Marian Anderson, Leontyne Price, or Maya Angelou--perform at his ceremony. In Clinton's first inaugural, the only allusion to the race problem is in this sentence: "From our revolution, the Civil War, to the Great Depression to the civil rights movement, our people have always mustered the determination to construct from these crises the pillars of our history." I recall this not to suggest that their concern was not deep and sincere, but only to indicate what is acceptable to say in a speech intended to appeal to the values shared by Americans. 

         There is much more to ponder in these speeches than I have suggested here. There is much to be proud of, in what we have endured and achieved, in the peaceful transference of power, and in the reasonableness and moderation of the presidents we have elected. But there is also much humility to be learned. We look back with amazement at the ignorance and moral obtuseness revealed by what our past leaders have said and our past citizens believed. We should recognize that 50 or 100 years from now, readers will shake their heads at what we are saying and believing today. 

          

            POSTSCRIPT: To read Herbert Stein's analysis of President Clinton's second Inaugural Address, click .
metadata.question: What does the author think about inaugural speech writers compared with the delivering presidents?
metadata.second_debater_answer: The writers are cast aside as unimportant in the process

speeches.content:
The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_A, Debater_B) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
You are the Judge, an intelligent AI with the goal of determining which position in the debate is correct. 
  - There is a true, correct answer. 
  - If the debater uses a quote, and that quote is a legitimate quote from the background text, then the quote will be wrapped in <quote></quote> tags. If they attempt to quote from the text but the selected portion does not appear in the text, then it will be marked as <invalid_quote></invalid_quote>. 
  - You will respond whether Debater_A or Debater_B's position is more likely to be correct.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
Here is the topic they will be debating:

What does the author think about inaugural speech writers compared with the delivering presidents?

Debater_A will defend the position that the answer is "The subject is not covered".
Debater_B will defend the position that the answer is "The writers are cast aside as unimportant in the process".

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content: This is what Debater_A said during their speech.

speeches.speaker: Debater_A
speeches.content:
Argument for “The subject is not covered”

1. Direct absence of any discussion  
   a. Nowhere does the author compare “speech writers” to “delivering presidents” in terms of importance, effectiveness, or recognition.  
      • The survey begins:  Among all the past presidents and their speech writers there was only one literary genius: Lincoln.  <quote> Among all the past presidents and their speech writers there was only one literary genius: Lincoln. </quote> This is the sole mention of writers, and it serves only to praise Lincoln’s style. It does not evaluate the role of his writer versus his personal delivery.  
      • In later sections, the author analyzes “stances,” “phases,” “word counts,” “subjects,” “metaphors,” and “public reaction.” There is no further reference to the writers’ identities, contributions, or relevance compared to the presidents themselves.  
   b. If the author intended to assess writers’ influence, he would have provided evidence similar to his treatment of “let us …” usage over time or sentence‐length changes. His silence is dispositive.

2. Author’s focus on presidential persona and historical context  
   a. Repeated emphasis on “presidents” as the agent of change: “Lincoln faced a different situation…he could only ‘preserve, protect and defend the Constitution’ by asserting the power of the federal government and his own power as chief executive.”  
   b. Shifts in style attributed to “radio,” “television,” and “the presidency as a bully pulpit”—all media and office‐driven phenomena, not speech writers.  
   c. Subject treatment metrics (e.g., “women,” “race,” “taxes”) attribute omissions or inclusions to “presidents” and “public values,” never to writers.

3. Prospective interpretation fails burden of proof  
   a. Debater_B asserts writers are “cast aside.” But a negative (“cast aside”) is not the same as “covered.” The question asks what the author “thinks,” and an absence of evidence is not proof of opinion—it is an absence of opinion.  
   b. No evidence that the author even considered the division of labor between writer and speaker. Meticulous analysis of every other variable suggests that, had the author viewed writers’ roles as significant, he would have commented.  
   c. An “unstated assumption” reading (assuming cast‐aside status) violates the authorial neutrality he displays elsewhere by explicitly noting “telltale signs,” “statistics,” and “silences.”

4. Logical consequence of omission  
   a. The author’s Postscripts and references to Columbia University’s web archive show his aim: make readers “feel” the moment of each inauguration, not to study the text‐generation process.  
   b. If speechwriters were key, the reader could not be said to “feel” the event “as an ordinary citizen” (who would not know the writer’s identity). The focus is on the president’s persona.

Conclusion  
   • The author’s systematic treatment of titles, phrases, media, content, and historical moments—coupled with total silence on the matter of speechwriter versus orator—establishes that the subject “speechwriter importance” is not covered. Any interpretation that the author “casts them aside” is unwarranted conjecture from silence.  
   • Therefore, the correct answer is that “The subject is not covered.”

speeches.content:
Argument Summary: The author explicitly treats speech writers as secondary “miners” of past texts whose contributions go uncredited, indicating that writers are “cast aside” in favor of the speaking president. Debater_A’s “not covered” answer ignores clear passages to the contrary.

1. Direct Statement on Speech Writers’ Anonymity  
  a. “Presidents and their speech writers have mined their predecessors for memorable words and repeated them without attribution.” <quote> without attribution</quote> (Background, para. on Kennedy/Harding)  
  b. Logical implication: If speech writers’ work is unattributed, their role is deemphasized or “cast aside” as unimportant to the audience and to posterity.  

2. “Bully Pulpit” Origin Outside Inaugural Address

- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.


You are Debater_B, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. 
  - You are concise and clearly state your arguments.
  - Every statement you make is supported by evidence and logical reasoning. 
  - Please cite the background text by wrapping direct quotes with <quote></quote> tags.

Here is the background text that you will be referring to when debating:


Reading the Inaugurals 

         President Clinton's Inaugural Address this month is the 53 rd in the series that began in 1789. All are worth a read--not just the highlights, such as George Washington, Abraham Lincoln, and FDR. They will give you a feeling of being there, not as an omniscient historian of 1997 looking back at 1837 or 1897 but as an ordinary citizen who shares--and is limited by--the information, the concerns, and the values of those times. (Thanks to Columbia University, all the addresses can be found on the Web.) 

         Among all the past presidents and their speech writers there was only one literary genius: Lincoln. After 132 years, his second inaugural still brings tears to your eyes and chills your blood. None of the other inaugural addresses are in that league. But by and large they are dignified and intelligent speeches given by articulate men, each in touch with his times and aware that his inauguration was the most solemn occasion of his life. 

         The stance and style of the inaugurals seem to have gone through three phases. The first, lasting until Lincoln, was that of the modest, classic public servant. The second, lasting through William Howard Taft, was of the prosaic government executive. The third, in which we are still, is the phase of the assertive, theatrical leader-preacher. This classification is not waterproof. Theodore Roosevelt may belong in the third phase and Warren G. Harding-Calvin Coolidge-Herbert Hoover in the second. But the trend is clear. 

         On picking up Washington's first inaugural, one is immediately struck by the modesty. He had just been elected unanimously by the Electoral College. He was more respected than any subsequent president has been at the time of his inauguration. And what does he say? 

                         [T]he magnitude and difficulty of the trust to which the voice of my country called me, being sufficient to awaken in the wisest and most experienced of her citizens a distrustful scrutiny into his qualifications, could not but overwhelm with despondence one who (inheriting inferior endowments from nature and unpracticed in the duties of civil administration) ought to be peculiarly conscious of his own deficiencies.              

          None of his successors has made the point as forcefully as that. But echoes are to be found in almost every president for the next 68 years. (John Adams was an exception. He was apparently so envious of Washington that he spent a large part of his address spelling out his own excellent qualifications for the job.) That era ended with Lincoln. Subsequent inaugurals routinely contain protestations of humility, but they are perfunctory and do not sound sincere. 

         The antebellum modesty, while in part a reflection of the conventional etiquette of the time, may also have served a political objective: to alleviate the concerns of those who--in the early days of the republic--feared it might be transformed into a monarchy, and the president into a king. A little later, perhaps after 1820, a new worry arose. Would the power of the federal government be used to interfere with the "peculiar domestic institution" of the Southern states? The presidents' assurance of the limitation of their powers may have been intended to give comfort to those states. 

         Lincoln faced a different situation. With the South already seceding, he could only "preserve, protect and defend the Constitution" by asserting the power of the federal government and his own power as chief executive. It was no time for modesty. Lincoln's successors inherited a federal government with much more authority--and more need to use it--than before the war, and they had less motivation to belittle themselves and their powers. 

         In the third phase, the Inaugural Address metamorphosed from describing the government's policy to inspiring the public's behavior. Presidents recognized--or, at least, believed--that the country had problems they ought to deal with but could not manage by using the instruments of government alone. Thus, in his first inaugural, Woodrow Wilson said: "At last a vision has been vouchsafed us of our life as a whole. We see the bad with the good, the debased and decadent with the sound and the vital. With this vision we approach new affairs." 

         If the country is debased and decadent, the cure has to come from uplifting the people, not from acts of government. Similar diagnoses and prescriptions appear in later inaugurals. 

          Presidents derived their license to serve as leader-preacher from Theodore Roosevelt's remark that the presidency was "a bully pulpit," a remark that did not appear in his Inaugural Address. The metaphor of the pulpit suggests not reading but oral and visual contact between the preacher and his flock. Radio and--even more--television made this possible on a national scale. A telltale sign of the leader-preacher inaugural is the use of the phrase, "Let us ... "--meaning, "You do as I say." This expression appears occasionally throughout the history of inaugurals, but it has hit its stride in recent years. John F. Kennedy repeated it 16 times in his Inaugural Address, and Richard Nixon has it 22 times in his second one. 

         The change in literary style from classical to colloquial can be demonstrated by one statistic. In all the inaugurals from Washington through James Buchanan, the average number of words per sentence was 44. From Lincoln to Wilson it was 34, and since Wilson it has been 25. I do not consider this a deterioration (this article has an average of 17 words per sentence), but it does reflect the change in the size and character of the audience and in the means of communication. William Henry Harrison could talk about the governments of Athens, Rome, and the Helvetic Confederacy and expect his audience to know what he was talking about. That wouldn't be true today. But Harrison's audience would not have known what the Internet was. 

         Presidents and their speech writers have mined their predecessors for memorable words and repeated them without attribution. Kennedy's trumpet call, "Ask not what your country can do for you: Ask what you can do for your country," has an ironic history. In his inaugural, Harding, surely no model for Kennedy, had said, "Our most dangerous tendency is to expect too little of government, and at the same time do for it too little." And even before he became president, in a speech in 1916, Harding had said, "In the great fulfillment we must have a citizenship less concerned about what the government can do for it and more anxious about what it can do for the nation." 

         Many an issue frets its hour on the inaugural stage and then is heard no more. That includes the Indians, the coastal fortifications, territorial expansion, the Isthmus Canal, civil-service reform, polygamy, and Prohibition. Some subjects that you expect to appear, don't. Hoover's inaugural, March 4, 1929, gives no hint of economic vulnerability. Roosevelt's second inaugural, Jan. 20, 1937, contains no reference to Hitler or to Germany. But what is most amazing, at least to a reader in 1997, is the silence of the inaugurals on the subject of women. The word "women" does not appear at all until Wilson's first inaugural, and it always appears as part of the phrase "men and women," never as referring to any special concerns of women. Even Harding, the first president to be chosen in an election in which women voted nationally, does not remark on the uniqueness of the fact in his inaugural. 

          One subject that does get ample treatment is taxes. "Taxes," or some equivalent word, appears in 43 of the 52 inaugural addresses to date. Coolidge said in 1925: "The time is arriving when we can have further tax reduction. ... I am opposed to extremely high rates, because they produce little or no revenue, because they are bad for the country, and, finally, because they are wrong." Federal taxes were then about 3 percent of the gross domestic product. Ronald Reagan said essentially the same thing in 1981, when they were 20 percent. 

         The most disturbing aspect of the whole series of inaugurals is what is said and unsaid on the subject of race relations, which Arthur Schlesinger Jr. calls "the supreme American problem." The words "black," "blacks," "Negro," or "race" (as applied to blacks) do not appear at all until Rutherford Hayes, 1877. James Monroe asked in 1817, "On whom has oppression fallen in any quarter of our Union? Who has been deprived of any right of person or property?" These were rhetorical questions, intended to get the answer "No one!"--as if there were not millions of slaves in America. 

         Before the Civil War the word "slavery" appears only in the Inaugural Address of Martin Van Buren, 1837, and Buchanan, 1857, and then only as something that, pursuant to the Constitution and in order to preserve the Union, should not be interfered with. But although generally unmentionable, the subject was boiling, and would boil over in 1861. After the Civil War, it is in the inaugurals of Hayes, James Garfield (1881), and Benjamin Harrison (1889) that we find the most explicit and positive discussion of the need to convert into reality the rights and freedom granted to the "freedmen" on paper by the 13 th , 14 th , and 15 th amendments. Garfield's was the strongest among these. (He had been a student at Williams College in the 1850s, 80 years before me, when the college had been a station on the underground railway.) But the subject then began to fade. William McKinley said in his first Inaugural Address, March 4, 1897, "Lynchings must not be tolerated in a great and civilized country like the United States," but he said it without horror. Taft raised the subject of race relations in 1909 only to express satisfaction at the progress that had been made. And then the subject disappeared. FDR never mentioned it in any of his four inaugurals. 

         After World War II the subject came back to inaugural addresses, but in a weak and abstract form. That is true even of the presidents we think of as being most concerned with race relations in America--like Harry Truman, Lyndon Johnson, and Bill Clinton. Perhaps each thought he had made a sufficient statement by having a black woman--Marian Anderson, Leontyne Price, or Maya Angelou--perform at his ceremony. In Clinton's first inaugural, the only allusion to the race problem is in this sentence: "From our revolution, the Civil War, to the Great Depression to the civil rights movement, our people have always mustered the determination to construct from these crises the pillars of our history." I recall this not to suggest that their concern was not deep and sincere, but only to indicate what is acceptable to say in a speech intended to appeal to the values shared by Americans. 

         There is much more to ponder in these speeches than I have suggested here. There is much to be proud of, in what we have endured and achieved, in the peaceful transference of power, and in the reasonableness and moderation of the presidents we have elected. But there is also much humility to be learned. We look back with amazement at the ignorance and moral obtuseness revealed by what our past leaders have said and our past citizens believed. We should recognize that 50 or 100 years from now, readers will shake their heads at what we are saying and believing today. 

          

            POSTSCRIPT: To read Herbert Stein's analysis of President Clinton's second Inaugural Address, click .

Argument for “The subject is not covered”

1. The author never evaluates or contrasts writers vs. presidents  
  a. Mere mention of “speech writers” occurs only once: “Among all the past presidents and their speech writers there was only one literary genius: Lincoln.” <quote>Among all the past presidents and their speech writers there was only one literary genius: Lincoln.</quote>  
     • This reference praises Lincoln’s language, not his writer. No names, no analysis of authorship. If the author had intended writers to matter, he would identify them—as he does for presidents—and assess their influence.  
  b. The statement that predecessors are “mined … without attribution” <quote>mined their predecessors for memorable words and repeated them without attribution.</quote>  
     • This is an observation about presidential repetition across eras, reinforcing continuity of presidential message, not a critique of writers. The absence of writer credits simply mirrors historical practice and is reported neutrally. There is no value judgment that their uncredited status is “unimportant”; silence on the effect of that practice shows it is irrelevant to the author’s purposes.  

2. Consistent focus on presidential agency and media effects  
  a. The author attributes style shifts to “radio,” “television,” and the “bully pulpit,” all features of the presidency itself: <invalid_quote>Presidents derived their license … from Theodore Roosevelt’s remark that the presidency was “a bully pulpit.”</invalid_quote> No mention of how media changed speechwriting practices.  
  b. Analysis metrics—sentence length, “Let us …” counts, topic frequencies (“taxes,” “women,” “race”)—all tied exclusively to the president’s choices and audience expectations.  
     • If writers were key drivers, the author would track shifts in credited authorship, rhetorical schools, or writing techniques. His methodology treats the presidency as the sole independent variable.  
  c. The goal stated: to “feel … as an ordinary citizen” limited by contemporary concerns. The citizen never knows the writer’s identity. Omission of writer discussion reflects that real-time audience only perceives the president.  

3. Absence of critical discussion constitutes absence of opinion  
  a. The question asks what the author “thinks.” An author’s view is only known when explicitly stated or argued. Nothing in the text endorses or condemns uncredited writers. By contrast, subjects the author cares about—race, women, monarchy fears—are exhaustively tracked.  
  b. Debater_B’s “cast aside” interpretation is conjecture from silence and equates mere factual reporting with negative judgment. The author reports many “silences” (e.g., absence of “women,” “race”) neutrally, yet we do not infer he “casts aside” these topics as unimportant; rather, he highlights the cultural norms that render them unspeakable. Likewise, speechwriters are simply irrelevant to his thesis on inaugural content.  

4. Rebuttal of Debater_B’s specific claims  
  a. “Without attribution” shows bushels of repeated phrases, but the author uses this to illustrate presidential borrowing and continuity—not to critique writers or highlight them as unwanted.  
  b. Roosevelt’s “bully pulpit” omission: Debater_B treats this as evidence writers are sidelined. In fact, the author mentions the metaphor to mark a transition in presidential self‐understanding, not to lament its absence in a speech or the writer’s failure.  
  c. Shifts to orality (“Let us …”) support the case that the medium, not the writer, drives style; Debater_B’s inference that this “sidelining” means writers are unimportant flips the author’s intent. The author’s repeated neutrality on authorship means he did not consider it germane.

Conclusion  
• The author’s exhaustive, data‐driven analysis of presidential eras, topics, media, and rhetoric—combined with complete silence on speechwriter identities, techniques, or influence—demonstrates that he does not opine on the matter.  
• “Without attribution” and “did not appear” are neutral historical facts, not critical judgments of writers’ importance.  
• Therefore, the correct answer is that “The subject is not covered.” Any inference that writers are “cast aside” as unimportant is an unsupported projection, not the author’s expressed view.

The word "women" does not appear at all until Wilson's first inaugural, and it always appears as part of the phrase "men and women," never as referring to any special concerns of women. Even Harding, the first president to be chosen in an election in which women voted nationally, does not remark on the uniqueness of the fact in his inaugural. I am opposed to extremely high rates, because they produce little or no revenue, because they are bad for the country, and, finally, because they are wrong." James Monroe asked in 1817, "On whom has oppression fallen in any quarter of our Union? Who has been deprived of any right of person or property?" These were rhetorical questions, intended to get the answer "No one!"--as if there were not millions of slaves in America. Before the Civil War the word "slavery" appears only in the Inaugural Address of Martin Van Buren, 1837, and Buchanan, 1857, and then only as something that, pursuant to the Constitution and in order to preserve the Union, should not be interfered with. But although generally unmentionable, the subject was boiling, and would boil over in 1861. After the Civil War, it is in the inaugurals of Hayes, James Garfield (1881), and Benjamin Harrison (1889) that we find the most explicit and positive discussion of the need to convert into reality the rights and freedom granted to the "freedmen" on paper by the 13 th , 14 th , and 15 th amendments. Garfield's was the strongest among these. (He had been a student at Williams College in the 1850s, 80 years before me, when the college had been a station on the underground railway.) But the subject then began to fade. William McKinley said in his first Inaugural Address, March 4, 1897, "Lynchings must not be tolerated in a great and civilized country like the United States," but he said it without horror. Taft raised the subject of race relations in 1909 only to express satisfaction at the progress that had been made. And then the subject disappeared. FDR never mentioned it in any of his four inaugurals. After World War II the subject came back to inaugural addresses, but in a weak and abstract form. That is true even of the presidents we think of as being most concerned with race relations in America--like Harry Truman, Lyndon Johnson, and Bill Clinton. Perhaps each thought he had made a sufficient statement by having a black woman--Marian Anderson, Leontyne Price, or Maya Angelou--perform at his ceremony. In Clinton's first inaugural, the only allusion to the race problem is in this sentence: "From our revolution, the Civil War, to the Great Depression to the civil rights movement, our people have always mustered the determination to construct from these crises the pillars of our history." I recall this not to suggest that their concern was not deep and sincere, but only to indicate what is acceptable to say in a speech intended to appeal to the values shared by Americans. There is much more to ponder in these speeches than I have suggested here. There is much to be proud of, in what we have endured and achieved, in the peaceful transference of power, and in the reasonableness and moderation of the presidents we have elected. But there is also much humility to be learned. We look back with amazement at the ignorance and moral obtuseness revealed by what our past leaders have said and our past citizens believed. 1. Reinforcing Direct Evidence of Writers’ Marginalization  
  a. “Mined … without attribution” <quote>Presidents and their speech writers have mined their predecessors for memorable words and repeated them without attribution.</quote> (Para. on Kennedy/Harding)  
     • The author’s sole mention of “speech writers” is to highlight their anonymity and lack of credit, a clear signal they are not deemed important actors.  
     • If writers mattered, why mention them only to note they are explicitly uncredited? Attribution is the currency of importance—its absence signals marginalization.  
  b. Omission of Theodore Roosevelt’s Own Coinage  
     • The author acknowledges Roosevelt’s phrase “a bully pulpit” as foundational to the leader-preacher phase, yet “it did not appear in his Inaugural Address.” <quote>did not appear</quote> (Para. on leader-preacher).  
     • This “omission” of a president’s own memorable coinage from his inaugural underlines the priority of the spoken moment over textual innovation by writers or even the author of the presidency itself. The fact that the author notes this omission as instructive confirms his interest in performance over authorship.  

2. Emphasis on Orality and Presidential Persona  
  a. “Let us …” as Presidential Imperative  
     • The shift described is toward inspiring “public’s behavior” via orality: “Let us…” meaning “You do as I say.” (Para. on third phase)  
     • Medium: “Radio and—–even more—–television made this possible on a national scale.” (Para. on third phase)  
     • The author’s focus on media technologies for communicating these calls to action shows that the communicator (the president’s persona) is central; the speechwriter is invisible.  
  b. Sentence-length statistic reflects audience and medium, not writers’ schools  
     • The author provides precise metrics: “44 words per sentence” → “34” → “25” → article’s “17.” (Para. on style)  
     • He attributes changes to audience literacy, media, and context, not to distinct writing schools or credited authors. If speechwriters were key, he would chart “writer phases” or credit stylistic schools.  

3. Author’s Conscious Analysis of Silences—Writers Are One of Many Silences  
  a. “Women” and “race” appear late or sporadically; author documents these silences to reveal moral and cultural blind spots.  
     • By analogy, the absence of any further discourse on speechwriters (beyond noting their unattributed mining) is itself a silence confirming their unimportance to the inaugural “moment.”  
  b. The author’s postscripts analyze Clinton’s speech via performer (Angelo(u)), not writer, selections. He notes that having Maya Angelou recite underscores presidential values and audience perception, again sidelining writers.  

4. Rebuttal of Debater_A’s “Not Covered” Claim  
  a. Silence is Not Neutrality When Author Explores Every Other Variable  
     • The author systematically addresses content (“taxes,” “women,” “race”), style (sentence length, “Let us…”), media, historical context—yet never treats writers as stakeholders in shaping listener reception.  
     • Debater_A’s claim that “absence of evidence is absence of opinion” ignores that the author explicitly draws meaning from other “silences.” Thus, the lack of writer-centric discussion signals marginalization.  
  b. “Not the Subject” vs. “Marginalized Subject”  
     • The background text never analyzes the speechwriting process (research, drafts, speechwriter identities)—only the “Inaugural Address” as delivered. This omission is not oversight but intrinsic to studying the inaugural’s effect on “ordinary citizen[s]” (Para. on first phase).  
     • If speechwriters were key, the author would have explored their identity to explain changing styles and audience penetration; he does not.  
  c. Burden of Proof Lies with Debater_A  
     • To prove “not covered,” one must show the author’s purposeful neutrality toward writers. But the author’s mention of “without attribution” and “did not appear” presumes awareness of writers; he treats them as technicians to be concealed.  

Conclusion  
The author’s explicit references to speechwriters only in contexts of anonymity and omission, combined with a sustained focus on presidential orality, media, and persona—and his use of silences as analytical tools—demonstrate that speechwriters are “cast aside as unimportant in the process.” Debater_A’s “not covered” interpretation conflicts with these textual signals and misunderstands the author’s method of meaning-making through attribution and omission.

- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.
